## REACT FLOW
- ** URL**: https://reactflow.dev/examples

### Validation
-**URL**: https://reactflow.dev/examples/interaction/validation
-**Use for**: Custom nodes need to have at least one Handle component to be connectable. You can pass a validation function isValidConnection to the ReactFlow component in order to check if a new connection is valid and should be added.

### Animating Edges
-**URL**: https://reactflow.dev/examples/edges/animating-edges
-**Use for**: React Flow provides a simple built-in animation for the default edge type, but it is possible to create more advanced animations by using custom edges. Below are a collection of examples showing different ways an edge path might be used in

### Simple Floating Edges
-**URL**: https://reactflow.dev/examples/edges/simple-floating-edges
-**Use for**: This is a simplified version of the Floating Edges example. Itâ€™s not as flexible as the floating edges example, but the edges stick to the top, right, bottom or left side of the nodes. You can find the implementation details in the utils.js file.

### Turbo Flow
-**URL**: https://reactflow.dev/examples/styling/turbo-flow
-**Use for**: Every part of the React Flow UI is customizable. As the name implies the look is taken from the beautiful turbo.build  website. You can find more information about custom styles in the theming guide. (React Flow uses Turborepo and we love it ðŸ’œ)

### Rectangle
-**URL**: https://reactflow.dev/examples/whiteboard/rectangle
-**Use for**: In this example, you can draw rectangles on a whiteboard. Click and drag to create a rectangle, and it will be added to the flow.
